Award.AwardTitle: C. elegans lipocalin function in growth factor signaling
Award.AbstractNarration: Cells use growth factors to communicate with each other and to instruct many different cellular behaviors during animal development. These growth factors must be tightly controlled over space and time to ensure that their instructions reach the appropriate target cells but are not given to inappropriate cells; otherwise, abnormal development will result. This project tests the hypothesis that lipocalins are direct modulators of growth factor signaling. Lipocalins are a large family of proteins found throughout the animal kingdom and implicated in small molecule transport, but their functions are poorly understood. Preliminary studies in the simple invertebrate organism Caenorhabditis elegans suggest that the lipocalin LPR-1 facilitates growth factor signaling during organ development, and may help retain this growth factor near its appropriate target cell. To understand the mechanisms underlying this regulation, the experimental aims are to: 1) Test if LPR-1 directly binds to any or all forms of the growth factor, using a combination of biochemical and transgenic studies; 2) Identify which parts of the LPR-1 protein are important for function, using transgenic studies; and 3) Identify other potential partners of LPR-1, using genetic screens. If LPR-1 acts as proposed, it should bind to the growth factor, and loss of the relevant binding domain should eliminate function. LPR-1 may also bind to other partners that help anchor it in place. These studies will provide significant new insights into how lipocalins function and uncover a novel mechanism of growth factor regulation that may be broadly relevant to other systems. The experiments will establish a new scientific collaboration and the project will provide training activities for a postdoctoral fellow and for multiple undergraduate students interested in scientific careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes report

Award Number 1257879 

 

Lipocalins are a large family of secreted proteins found throughout animals and often present in luminal or apical extracellular environments such as mammalian blood, urine and tear film. Some human lipocalins are used as clinical biomarkers because their levels increase upon tissue damage. Lipocalins can bind and transport lipids and other small lipophilic compounds, and have been proposed to exert a wide variety of functions related to signaling and the protection of tissue integrity. However, the functions of most lipocalins are not well understood.

 

Our studies revealed that multiple lipocalins in the nematode C. elegans are required for synthesis and/or remodeling of the apical extracellular matrix (ECM). The apical ECM is a multi-layered structure composed of lipids, sugars and proteins. It lines exposed surfaces of the body (including tube lumens), protects them from pathogens and other environmental insults, and contributes to structural and barrier properties of tissues. We found that C. elegans embryos develop in the context of an apical ECM that has many molecular similarities to the apical ECM of mammals. Changes in the apical ECM can explain the tissue integrity defects observed in our C. elegans mutants lacking lipocalins, and may also explain many effects of lipocalins on human health.

 

We began this work with the hypothesis that the lipocalin LPR-1 facilitates growth factor signaling. However, genetic and biochemical data we obtained argued against that model, and instead suggested that LPR-1 and growth factor signaling have separate (but cooperating) inputs into tissue protection. We then searched for other genes or pathways that might act more directly with the lipocalin LPR-1. These studies identified a second lipocalin and multiple other secreted or transmembrane glycoproteins that are part of the C. elegans apical ECM. We found that lipocalins localize adjacent to apical ECM glycoproteins, and loss of either causes the same spectrum of defects in narrow tube integrity and cuticle structure. We also discovered genetic changes in another putative lipid transport protein that can cure defects caused by loss of LPR-1 or other apical ECM glycoproteins. These data lead to a new hypothesis that lipocalins affect the lipid content of the apical ECM.

 

This research has been carried out by mentored trainees, including undergraduate students from under-represented groups and post-baccalaureate technicians. Several of these trainees have subsequently entered graduate school, and will contribute to the scientific work force.
